content: The "Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2000" is also known as the Fair Treatment of Airline Passengers Act. The "Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2000" is also known as the Fair Treatment of Airline Passengers Act. Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include specific practices related to unfair or deceptive practices by air carriers, such as inaccurate explanations for flight delays and restrictive pricing policies. The "Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2000" includes provisions to address unfair practices by air carriers, such as using only a portion of purchased air transportation or imposing additional fees on passengers or ticket agents. In cases of termination or changes in ticket agent appointments, carriers must provide written notice and reasons for their actions. The "Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2000" requires carriers to give written notice and reasons for termination or changes in ticket agent appointments, allowing 90 days notice and 60 days to correct any deficiencies. SEC. 3. Amends Section 41713(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code, regarding enforcement of state laws related to air carrier prices, routes, and services. SEC. 4. Addresses emergency medical assistance and the right of egress. The Secretary of Transportation will establish regulations for emergency medical equipment on aircraft with at least 30 passengers. Considerations include equipment size, weight, and personnel training. The Secretary of Transportation will establish regulations for emergency medical equipment on aircraft with at least 30 passengers, considering factors such as personnel training, aircraft space limitations, regulations' impact on operations, airlines' practical experience, and other relevant factors. Consultation with the Surgeon General is required before prescribing these regulations. Air carriers must allow passengers to exit the aircraft under the same circumstances as flight crew members. The regulations allow passengers to exit the aircraft if it has been parked at the gate for over an hour past its scheduled departure time and the captain has not been informed of imminent departure clearance. SEC. 5. ENSURING CONSUMER ACCESS TO TRAVEL INFORMATION. The National Commission to Ensure Consumer Information and Choice in the Airline Industry is established to study consumer access to airline industry information, the impact of new distribution methods, the financial struggles of travel agents, and the obstacles faced by distributors. The National Commission to Ensure Consumer Information and Choice in the Airline Industry will recommend policies to ensure consumer access to complete information about airline fares and routes, adequate distribution of airline products, and relief for distributors in the industry. The National Commission aims to ensure consumer access to information in the airline industry, address anticompetitive practices, and promote healthy competition. Specific matters to be addressed include consumer access to information, the impact of alliances, and the benefits to consumers. The curr_chunk discusses the means of distributing products and services in the airline industry, including the roles of travel agencies and internet-based providers. It also addresses airline reservation systems and how trends in these systems will impact consumers. The curr_chunk discusses the impact on consumer access to flight reservation information and the use of penalties and promotions by the airline industry to influence distributors. It also addresses legal impediments for distributors seeking relief for anticompetitive actions, including federal preemption of civil actions against airlines and the role of the Department of Transportation. The Commission consists of 15 voting members and 11 nonvoting members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Minority Leader of the Senate. The Commission consists of 15 voting members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, and Minority Leader of the Senate. Voting members must be experts in economics, transportation, or related disciplines, and represent consumers, passengers, shippers, travel agents, airlines, or general aviation. Members serve for life and receive travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson of the Commission is designated by the President in consultation with other officials. The Chairperson can establish panels with voting members as needed. The Commission can appoint personnel and request staff from federal agencies for assistance. The Commission can request staff and support from the Secretary of Transportation on a reimbursable basis. It can also obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. A report is due within 1 year of initial Commission appointments. The Commission will report its activities and recommendations to the President and Congress upon completion of member appointments. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report, with all records transferred to the National Archives. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission.
